title: 106_s2511
content: The Act titled "Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area Act of 2000" is established for the purpose of preserving the heritage area. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm transportation corridor in Alaska is a significant gateway with a rich history of indigenous people and pioneers. The region's natural beauty includes evidence of earthquakes, avalanches, glaciers, and tidal action. The cultural landscape reflects human fortitude, perseverance, and resourcefulness. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm region in Alaska has a rich history and natural beauty, with a national interest in recognizing and preserving its historical routes and landmarks. This includes the Iditarod National Historic Trail, the Seward Highway National Scenic Byway, and the Alaska Railroad National Scenic Railroad. National heritage area designation allows for the interpretation of these routes and the region's significance. The national heritage area designation in the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm region supports grassroots coordination and partnerships among communities and various historical associations. The national heritage area designation in the Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm region supports coordination among various historical associations and community groups for the recognition, preservation, and interpretation of historic and modern resource development and cultural landscapes. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm historic transportation corridor aims to preserve cultural landscapes and promote public enjoyment. It also supports cooperative planning and partnerships among communities and government entities through financial and technical assistance. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area, established by this Act, includes a management entity responsible for implementing a management plan. The Secretary of the Interior oversees the Heritage Area. The Kenai Mountains-Turnagain Arm National Heritage Area is established with defined boundaries in the Kenai Mountains and upper Turnagain Arm region. A management entity is responsible for implementing a management plan under the oversight of the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary will enter a cooperative agreement with the management entity for the Heritage Area, outlining objectives, conservation approach, and protection measures. The management entity is not authorized to manage Federal lands. Other organizations are encouraged to participate in the management plan development. The management plan for the Heritage Area involves collaboration with various organizations, and ex officio members will be represented in the nonprofit corporation according to the bylaws of the management entity. The management entity has authorities and duties outlined in Section 6. The management entity, within 3 years of the cooperative agreement, must develop a management plan for the Heritage Area, considering various existing plans. The plan should include recommendations for conservation, funding, and agreements with government and private organizations for resource protection and funding sources. The management entity must develop a management plan for the Heritage Area within 3 years of the cooperative agreement. The plan should prioritize actions, goals, and policies from the cooperative agreement and heritage plan, including programs for resource recognition, economic viability, and interpretive exhibits. The management entity is responsible for establishing interpretive exhibits, improving heritage trails, increasing public awareness of resources, restoring historic buildings, and ensuring clear signage in the Heritage Area. They must also conduct at least 2 public meetings annually to discuss the management plan implementation. The management entity is responsible for improving heritage trails, restoring historic buildings, and conducting public meetings to discuss the management plan implementation. They shall place a notice of each meeting in a newspaper and make the minutes available to the public. The Secretary, in consultation with the Governor of Alaska, may enter into a cooperative agreement with the management entity for public participation. The Secretary can provide assistance as requested by the management entity to carry out the purposes of the Act. Savings provisions are also included. SEC. 8. SAVINGS PROVISIONS: This Act does not grant zoning powers to the Heritage Area management entity. It does not affect the authority of governments to regulate land use. It also does not restrict business activities. SEC. 9. PROHIBITION ON PROPERTY ACQUISITION: The management entity cannot use funds to acquire real property. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $350,000 authorized for the first year, $1,000,000 for subsequent years. Maximum of $10,000,000 for the Heritage Area. Federal funding requires a 25% match. No grants beyond 15 years from cooperative agreement completion. The bill was passed by the Senate on September 22, 2000. Gary Sisco attested as Secretary.
